step1.sentence: She set a goal at the beginning of the year and checked in on it every month.

step2.story: The coach set team goals collaboratively — not numbers imposed from above but targets the players had helped choose. The buy-in, he found, mattered more than the precision of the target.

step3.story: The productivity researcher had studied goal-setting across cultures and industries for fifteen years. Her most consistent finding was not that people failed to reach their goals — most people who set clear, specific goals did reach them at a reasonable rate. The problem was that most people did not set goals in the first place, or set them so vaguely that achievement was unmeasurable. Setting a good goal, she had concluded, was itself a skill that required practice, and it was rarely taught anywhere formally.

meaning.shortExampleEn: Set a goal that challenges you but is still realistic.
